arguments.description: Enables the user to control the level of primal heuristics applied by the MILP solver.

arguments.name: AUTOMATIC
arguments.description: Apply default level of heuristics, similar to MODERATE.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Disable all primal heuristics.

arguments.name: BASIC
arguments.description: Apply basic primal heuristics at low frequency.

arguments.name: MODERATE
arguments.description: Apply most primal heuristics at moderate frequency.

arguments.name: AGGRESSIVE
arguments.description: Apply all primal heuristics at high frequency.

arguments.name: INTTOL=
arguments.description: Specifies the amount by which an integer variable value can differ from an integer and still be considered integer feasible. The value of num can be any number between 0.0 and 1.0; the default value is 1E-5.

arguments.name: LOGFREQ=
arguments.description: Specifies how often information is printed in the node log. The value of number can be any nonnegative integer up to the largest four-byte signed integer, which is 2³¹-1.

arguments.name: LOGLEVEL=
arguments.description: Controls the amount of information displayed in the SAS log by the MILP solver, from a short description of presolve information and summary to details at each node.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Turn off all solver-related messages in SAS log.

arguments.name: BASIC
arguments.description: Display a solver summary after stopping.

arguments.name: MODERATE
arguments.description: Print a solver summary and a node log by using the interval dictated by the PRINTFREQ= option.

arguments.name: AGGRESSIVE
arguments.description: Print a detailed solver summary and a node log by using the interval dictated by the PRINTFREQ= option.

arguments.name: MAXNODES=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of branch-and-bound nodes to be processed. The value of num can be any nonnegative integer up to the largest four-byte signed integer, which is 2³¹-1. The default value is 2³¹-1.

arguments.name: MAXSOLS=
arguments.description: Specifies a stopping criterion. If num solutions have been found, then the procedure stops. The value of num can be any positive integer up to the largest four-byte signed integer, which is 2³¹-1. The default value is 2³¹-1.

arguments.name: MAXTIME=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum time allowed for the MILP solver to find a solution.

arguments.name: NODESEL=
arguments.description: Specifies the node selection strategy string or its corresponding value number. Specifies the node selection strategy option.

arguments.name: AUTOMATIC
arguments.description: Use automatic node selection.

arguments.name: BESTBOUND
arguments.description: Choose the node with the best relaxed objective (best-bound-first strategy).

arguments.name: BESTESTIMATE
arguments.description: Choose the node with the best estimate of the integer objective value (best-estimate-first strategy).

arguments.name: DEPTH
arguments.description: Choose the most recently created node (depth-first strategy).

arguments.name: OPTTOL=
arguments.description: Specifies the tolerance used to determine the optimality of nodes in the branch-and-bound tree. The value of number can be any value between (and including) 1E–4 and 1E–9. The default is 1E–6.

arguments.name: PRESOLVER=
arguments.description: Specifies a presolve option.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Disable presolver.

arguments.name: AUTOMATIC
arguments.description: Apply the default level of presolve processing.

arguments.name: BASIC
arguments.description: Perform minimal presolve processing.

arguments.name: MODERATE
arguments.description: Apply a higher level of presolve processing.

arguments.name: AGGRESSIVE
arguments.description: Apply the highest level of presolve processing.

arguments.name: PRIMALIN
arguments.description: Enables you to input an integer feasible solution in PROC OPTMODEL before invoking the MILP solver. Adding the PRIMALIN option to the SOLVE statement requests that the MILP solver use the current variable values as a starting integer feasible solution (warm start). If the MILP solver finds that the input solution is valid, then the input solution provides an incumbent solution and a bound for the branch-and-bound algorithm. If the solution is not valid, then the PRIMALIN data are ignored.

arguments.name: PRIORITY=
arguments.description: Indicates whether to use specified branching priorities for integer variables.
Ignores variable priorities.
Uses priorities when they exist. This is the default.

arguments.name: PROBE=
arguments.description: Specifies a probing option.

arguments.name: AUTOMATIC
arguments.description: Probing strategy determined by the MILP solver.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Disable probing.

arguments.name: MODERATE
arguments.description: Use probing moderately.

arguments.name: AGGRESSIVE
arguments.description: Use probing aggressively.

arguments.name: RELOBJGAP=
arguments.description: Specifies a stopping criterion based on the best integer objective (BestInteger) and the objective of the best remaining node (BestBound).

arguments.name: RESTARTS=
arguments.description: Specifies the strategy for restarting the processing of the root node.

arguments.name: AUTOMATIC
arguments.description: Uses a restarting strategy determined by the MILP solver

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Disables restarting

arguments.name: BASIC
arguments.description: Uses a basic restarting strategy

arguments.name: MODERATE
arguments.description: Uses a moderate restarting strategy

arguments.name: AGGRESSIVE
arguments.description: Uses an aggressive restarting strategy

arguments.name: SCALE=
arguments.description: Indicates whether or not to scale the problem matrix.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Disables scaling.

arguments.name: AUTOMATIC
arguments.description: Scales the matrix as determined by the MILP solver. This is the default.

arguments.name: SEED=
arguments.description: Specifies the initial seed of the random number generator.

arguments.name: STRONGITER=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of simplex iterations performed for each variable in the candidate list when using the strong branching variable selection strategy. The value of num can be any positive number up to the largest four-byte signed integer, which is 2^31 - 1. If you specify the keyword AUTOMATIC or the value –1, the MILP solver uses the default value; this value is calculated automatically.

arguments.name: STRONGLEN=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of candidates used when the strong branching variable selection strategy is performed. The value of number can be any positive integer up to the largest four-byte signed integer, which is 2^31 - 1. If you specify the keyword AUTOMATIC or the value –1, the MILP solver uses the default value; this value is calculated automatically.

arguments.name: SYMMETRY=
arguments.description: Specifies the level of symmetry detection. Symmetry detection identifies groups of equivalent decision variables and uses this information to solve the problem more efficiently.

arguments.name: AUTOMATIC
arguments.description: Performs symmetry detection based on a strategy that is determined by the MILP solver

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Disables symmetry detection

arguments.name: BASIC
arguments.description: Performs a basic symmetry detection

arguments.name: MODERATE
arguments.description: Performs a moderate symmetry detection

arguments.name: AGGRESSIVE
arguments.description: Performs an aggressive symmetry detection

arguments.name: TARGET=
arguments.description: Specifies a stopping criterion for minimization (maximization) problems. If the best integer objective is better than or equal to num, the procedure stops. The value of num can be any number; the default value is the negative (positive) number that has the largest absolute value representable in your operating environment.

arguments.name: TIMETYPE=
arguments.description: Specifies the measurement of time used by the MILP solver.

arguments.name: CPU
arguments.description: Uses CPU time. This is the default.

arguments.name: REAL
arguments.description: Uses real time.

arguments.name: VARSEL=
arguments.description: Specifies the rule for selecting the branching variable.

arguments.name: AUTOMATIC
arguments.description: Use automatic branching variable selection.

arguments.name: MAXINFEAS
arguments.description: Choose the variable with maximum infeasibility.

arguments.name: MININFEAS
arguments.description: Choose the variable with minimum infeasibility.

arguments.name: PSEUDO
arguments.description: Choose a branching variable based on pseudocost.

arguments.name: STRONG
arguments.description: Use strong branching variable selection strategy.

statements.name: SOLVE WITH NETWORK
statements.description: The SOLVE WITH NETWORK statement invokes the network solver.
statements.help: SOLVE WITH NETWORK NOOBJECTIVE OBJECTIVE RELAXINT ...

arguments.name: NOOBJECTIVE
arguments.description: Requests that the solver ignore the current objective for the problem and use a constant zero objective instead. This keyword enables the solver to process the current model as a feasibility problem.

arguments.name: OBJECTIVE
arguments.description: A keyword used when specifying the name of the objective to use.

arguments.name: RELAXINT
arguments.description: Requests that any integral variables be relaxed to be continuous. RELAXINT can be used with linear and nonlinear problems in addition to any solver.

arguments.name: BICONCOMP
arguments.description: Finds biconnected components and articulation points of an undirected input graph.

arguments.name: CLIQUE=
arguments.description: Finds maximal cliques in the input graph. You can specify the following suboption:

arguments.name: CONCOMP=
arguments.description: Finds the connected components of the input graph. You can specify the following suboption:

arguments.name: CYCLE=
arguments.description: Finds the cycles (or the existence of a cycle) in the input graph. You can specify the following suboptions in the CYCLE= option:
arguments.help: CYCLE=MAXCYCLES= | MAXLENGTH= | MAXLINKWEIGHT= | MAXNODEWEIGHT= | MINLENGTH= | MINLINKWEIGHT= | MINNODEWEIGHT= | MODE=

arguments.name: GRAPH_DIRECTION=
arguments.description: Specifies directed or undirected graphs.

arguments.name: DIRECTED
arguments.description: Requests a directed graph.

arguments.name: UNDIRECTED
arguments.description: Requests an undirected graph.

arguments.name: INCLUDE_SELFLINK
arguments.description: Includes self links in the graph definition—for example, $(i,i)$—when an input graph is read. By default, when the network solver reads the LINKS= data, it removes all self links.

arguments.name: LINKS=
arguments.description: Groups link-indexed data. You can specify the following suboptions: INCLUDE=set-name names a set of links to include in the graph definition even if no weights or bounds are available for them. LOWER=array-name specifies the flow lower bound for each link. The array must be numeric, and it must be indexed over a subset of the inks of the graph. UPPER=array-name specifies the flow upper bound for each link. The array must be numeric, and it must be indexed over a subset of the links of the graph.

arguments.name: LOGFREQ=
arguments.description: Controls the frequency with which an algorithm reports progress from its underlying solver. This setting is recognized by the traveling salesman problem and minimum-cost flow algorithms. You can set number to 0 to turn off log updates from underlying algorithms.

arguments.name: LOGLEVEL=
arguments.description: Controls the amount of information that is displayed in the SAS log. This setting sets the log level for all algorithms. The following describes the valid values of the this option. number string Description 0 NONE Turns off all procedure-related messages in the SAS log 1 BASIC Displays a basic summary of the input, output, and algorithmic processing 2 MODERATE Displays a summary of the input, output, and algorithmic processing 3 AGGRESSIVE Displays a detailed summary of the input, output, and algorithmic processing

arguments.name: MAXTIME=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum time to spend calculating results. The type of time (either CPU time or real time) is determined by the value of the TIMETYPE= option. The value of number can be any positive number; the default value is the positive number that has the largest absolute value that can be represented in your operating environment.

arguments.name: MINCOSTFLOW=
arguments.description: Solves the minimum-cost network flow problem.

arguments.name: MINCUT=
arguments.description: Finds the minimum link-weighted cut of an input graph. You can specify the following suboptions in the MINCUT= option: MAXNUMCUTS=number specifies the maximum number of cuts to return from the algorithm. The minimal cut and any others found during the search, up to number, are returned. By default, MAXNUMCUTS=1.

arguments.name: MINSPANTREE=
arguments.description: Solves the minimum link-weighted spanning tree problem on an input graph.

arguments.name: NODES=
arguments.description: Groups node-indexed data. You can specify the following suboptions: INCLUDE=set-name names a set of nodes to include in the graph definition even if no weights are available for them. WEIGHT=array-name specifies node weights. The array must be numeric, and it must be indexed over a subset of the nodes of the graph.

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: Specifies the output sets or arrays for each algorithm. You can specify the following suboptions:
arguments.help: OUT=ARTPOINTS= | ASSIGNMENTS= | BICONCOMP= | CLIQUES= | CONCOMP= | CUTSETS= | CYCLES= | FLOW= | FOREST= | LINKS= | NODES= | ORDER= | PARTITIONS= | SPPATHS= | TOUR= | SPWEIGHTS= | TRANSCL=

arguments.name: SHORTPATH=
arguments.description: Calculates shortest paths between sets of nodes on the input graph. You can specify the following suboptions:

arguments.name: SUBGRAPH=
arguments.description: Specifies the input sets that enable you to solve a problem over a subgraph. You can specify the following suboptions: LINKS=set-name specifies the subset of links to use. If you specify a node pair that is not referenced in any of the suboptions of the LINKS= option, then the network solver returns an error.

arguments.name: TIMETYPE=
arguments.description: Specifies whether to use CPU time or real time for the MAXTIME= option. The following describes the valid values of the TIMETYPE= option. number string Description 0 CPU Specifies units of CPU time 1 REAL Specifies units of real time

arguments.name: TRANSITIVE_CLOSURE=
arguments.description: Calculates the transitive closure of an input graph.

arguments.name: TSP=
arguments.description: Solves the traveling salesman problem. The algorithm that is used to solve this problem is built around the same method as is used in PROC OPTMILP: a branch-and-cut algorithm. Many of the following suboptions are the same as those described for the OPTMILP procedure in the SAS/OR User's Guide: Mathematical Programming. You can specify the following suboptions:
arguments.help: TSP=ABSOBJGAP= | CONFLICTSEARCH= | CUTOFF= | CUTSTRATEGY= | EMPHASIS= | HEURISTICS= | MAXNODES= | MAXSOLS= | MILP= | NODESEL= | PROBE= | RELOBJGAP= | STRONGITER= | STRONGLEN= | TARGET= | VARSEL=

statements.name: SOLVE WITH NLP
statements.description: where options specify the technique name, termination criteria, and how to display the results in the iteration log. The sparse nonlinear programming (NLP) solver is a component of the OPTMODEL procedure that can solve optimization problems containing both nonlinear equality and inequality constraints.
statements.help: SOLVE WITH NLP NOOBJECTIVE OBJECTIVE RELAXINT ...

arguments.name: NOOBJECTIVE
arguments.description: Requests that the solver ignore the current objective for the problem and use a constant zero objective instead. This keyword enables the solver to process the current model as a feasibility problem.

arguments.name: OBJECTIVE
arguments.description: A keyword used when specifying the name of the objective to use.

arguments.name: RELAXINT
arguments.description: Requests that any integral variables be relaxed to be continuous. RELAXINT can be used with linear and nonlinear problems in addition to any solver.

arguments.name: ALGORITHM=
arguments.description: Specifies the optimization technique to be used to solve the problem.

arguments.name: INTERIORPOINT
arguments.description: Uses a primal-dual interior point method. This technique is recommended for both small- and large-scale nonlinear optimization problems. This is the preferred solver if the problem includes a large number of inactive constraints.

arguments.name: ACTIVESET
arguments.description: Uses a primal-dual active-set method. This technique is recommended for both small- and largescale nonlinear optimization problems. This is the preferred solver if the problem includes only bound constraints or if the optimal active set can be quickly determined by the solver.

arguments.name: CONCURRENT
arguments.description: Runs the INTERIORPOINT and ACTIVESET techniques in parallel, with one thread using the INTERIORPOINT technique and the other thread using the ACTIVESET technique. The solution is returned by the first method that terminates.

arguments.name: COVEST=
arguments.description: Requests that the NLP solver produce a covariance matrix. When this option is applied, the following PROC OPTMODEL options are automatically set: PRESOLVER=NONE and SOLTYPE=0. You can specify the following suboptions:
arguments.help: COVEST=ASINGULAR= | COV= | COVOUT= | COVSING= | MSINGULAR= | NDF= | NTERMS= | SIGSQ= | VARDEF=

arguments.name: FEASTOL=
arguments.description: Defines the feasible tolerance. The solver will exit if the constraint violation is less than FEASTOL and the scaled optimality conditions are less than OPTTOL. The default is ɛ=1E–6.

arguments.name: HESSTYPE=
arguments.description: Specifies the type of Hessian to be used by the solver. The valid keywords for this option are FULL and PRODUCT.

arguments.name: FULL
arguments.description: If HESSTYPE=FULL, the solver uses a full Hessian.

arguments.name: PRODUCT
arguments.description: If HESSTYPE=PRODUCT, the solver uses only Hessian-vector products, not the full Hessian.

arguments.name: IIS=
arguments.description: IIS=number | string Specifies whether the NLP solver attempts to identify a set of linear constraints and variables that form an irreducible infeasible set (IIS).

arguments.name: OFF
arguments.description: Disables IIS detection.

arguments.name: ON
arguments.description: Enables IIS detection.

arguments.name: LOGFREQ=
arguments.description: Specifies how often the iterations are displayed in the SAS log. N should be an integer between zero and the largest four-byte, signed integer, which is 2³¹ - 1. If N >= 1, the solver prints only those iterations that are a multiple of N. If N = 0, no iteration is displayed in the log. The default value is 1.

arguments.name: MAXITER=
arguments.description: Specifies that the solver take at most N major iterations to determine an optimum of the NLP problem. The value of N is an integer between zero and the largest four-byte, signed integer, which is 2ⁿ - 1 (where n-31). A major iteration in NLP consists of finding a descent direction and a step size along which the next approximation of the optimum resides. The default is 5,000 iterations.

arguments.name: MAXTIME=
arguments.description: Specifies an upper limit of t units of time for the optimization process, including problem generation time and solution time. The value of the TIMETYPE= option determines the type of units used. If you do not specify the MAXTIME= option, the solver does not stop based on the amount of time elapsed. The value of t can be any positive number; the default value is the positive number that has the largest absolute value that can be represented in your operating environment.

arguments.name: MSBNDRANGE=
arguments.description: Defines the range from which each variable can take values during the sampling process. This option affects only the sampling process that determines starting points for the local solver. It does not affect the bounds of the original nonlinear optimization problem.

arguments.name: MSDISTTOL=
arguments.description: defines the tolerance by which two optimal points are considered distinct. Optimal points are considered distinct if the Euclidean distance between them is at least ϵ. This option is effective only when the MULTISTART option is specified. The default is ϵ=1.0E–6.

arguments.name: MSLOGLEVEL=
arguments.description: Defines the amount of information displayed in the SAS log by the MULTISTART option.
Turns off all solver-related messages to SAS log
Displays multistart summary information when the algorithm terminates
Displays multistart iteration log and summary information when the algorithm terminates
Displays the same information as MSLOGLEVEL=2 and might display additional information

arguments.name: MSMAXSTARTS=
arguments.description: Defines the maximum number of starting points to be used for local optimization. That is, there will be no more than N local optimization calls in the multistart algorithm. You can specify N to be any nonnegative integer. When N = 0, the algorithm uses the default value of this option. In a shared memory computing environment, the default value is 100. In a distributed computing environment, the default value is a number proportional to the number of threads across all the grid nodes (usually more than 100). This option is effective only when the MULTISTART option is specified.

arguments.name: MSMAXTIME=
arguments.description: Defines the maximum allowable time T (in seconds) for the NLP solver to locate the best local optimum in multistart mode. The value of the TIMETYPE= option determines the type of units used.

arguments.name: MULTISTART=
arguments.description: Enables multistart mode. In this mode, the local solver solves the problem from multiple starting points, possibly finding a better local minimum as a result. This option is disabled by default.
arguments.help: MULTISTART=BNDRANGE= | DISTTOL= | LOGLEVEL= | PRINTLEVEL= | MAXTIME= | MAXSTARTS=

arguments.name: OBJLIMIT=
arguments.description: Specifies an upper limit on the magnitude of the objective value. For a minimization problem, the algorithm terminates when the objective value becomes less than -M; for a maximization problem, \ the algorithm stops when the objective value exceeds M. The algorithm stopping implies that either the problem is unbounded or the algorithm diverges. If optimization were allowed to continue, numerical difficulty might be encountered. The default is M=1E+20. The minimum acceptable value of M is 1E+8. If the specified value of M is less than 1E+8, the value is reset to the default value 1E+20.

arguments.name: OPTTOL=
arguments.description: Defines the measure by which you can decide whether the current iterate is an acceptable approximation of a local minimum. The value of this option is a positive real number. The NLP solver determines that the current iterate is a local minimum when the norm of the scaled vector of the optimality conditions is less than ϵ and the true constraint violation is less than FEASTOL. The default is ɛ=1E–6.

arguments.name: SEED=
arguments.description: Specifies a positive integer to be used as the seed for generating random number sequences. You can use this option to replicate results from different runs.

arguments.name: SOLTYPE=
arguments.description: Specifies whether the NLP solver should return only a solution that is locally optimal. If SOLTYPE=0, the solver returns a locally optimal solution, provided it locates one. If SOLTYPE=1, the solver returns the best feasible solution found, provided its objective value is better than that of the locally optimal solution found. The default is 1.
The solver returns a locally optimal solution, provided it locates one.
The solver returns the best feasible solution found, provided its objective value is better than that of the locally optimal solution found.

arguments.name: TIMETYPE=
arguments.description: Specifies the units of time used by the MAXTIME= option and reported by the PRESOLVE_TIME and SOLUTION_TIME terms in the _OROPTMODEL_ macro variable.

arguments.name: CPU
arguments.description: Specifies units of CPU time

arguments.name: REAL
arguments.description: Specifies units of real time

statements.name: SOLVE WITH NLPC
statements.description: Statement for specifying and solving general nonlinear programming problems.
statements.help: SOLVE WITH NLPC NOOBJECTIVE OBJECTIVE RELAXINT ...

arguments.name: NOOBJECTIVE
arguments.description: Requests that the solver ignore the current objective for the problem and use a constant zero objective instead. This keyword enables the solver to process the current model as a feasibility problem.

arguments.name: OBJECTIVE
arguments.description: A keyword used when specifying the name of the objective to use.

arguments.name: RELAXINT
arguments.description: Requests that any integral variables be relaxed to be continuous. RELAXINT can be used with linear and nonlinear problems in addition to any solver.

arguments.name: ABSOPTTOL=
arguments.description: Specifies the tolerance for the absolute optimality error.

arguments.name: MAXFUNC=
arguments.description: Specifies that the optimization process stop after a maximum of N function calls.

arguments.name: MAXITER=
arguments.description: Specifies that the optimization process stop after a maximum of N iterations.

arguments.name: MAXTIME=
arguments.description: Specifies an upper limit of M seconds of real time for the optimization process.

arguments.name: OBJLIMIT=
arguments.description: Specifies an upper limit on the magnitude of the objective value. For a minimization problem, the algorithm terminates when the objective value becomes less than -M; for a maximization problem, \ the algorithm stops when the objective value exceeds M.

arguments.name: PRINTFREQ=
arguments.description: Specifies that the printing of the solution progress to the iteration log should occur after every j iterations.

arguments.name: RELOPTTOL=
arguments.description: Specifies the tolerance for the relative optimality error.

arguments.name: TECHNIQUE=
arguments.description: Specifies the optimization technique.

arguments.name: CONGRA
arguments.description: Uses a conjugate gradient method.

arguments.name: NEWTYP
arguments.description: Uses a Newton-type method with line search.

arguments.name: TRUREG
arguments.description: Uses a trust region method.

arguments.name: QUANEW
arguments.description: Uses a quasi-Newton method with the BFGS update. QUANEW is the optimization technique in the NLPC solver to solve problems with nonlinear constraints.

statements.name: SOLVE WITH NLPU
statements.description: Statement for specifying and solving unconstrained nonlinear programming problems.
statements.help: SOLVE WITH NLPU NOOBJECTIVE OBJECTIVE RELAXINT ...

arguments.name: NOOBJECTIVE
arguments.description: Requests that the solver ignore the current objective for the problem and use a constant zero objective instead. This keyword enables the solver to process the current model as a feasibility problem.

arguments.name: OBJECTIVE
arguments.description: A keyword used when specifying the name of the objective to use.

arguments.name: RELAXINT
arguments.description: Requests that any integral variables be relaxed to be continuous. RELAXINT can be used with linear and nonlinear problems in addition to any solver.

arguments.name: LBFGSCORR=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of Hessian corrections for the L-BFGS algorithms. The value of n can be any integer between 2 and 100. The default value is 7 corrections.

arguments.name: LSARMIJO=
arguments.description: Specifies the Armijo parameter c1 for the line-search technique. The default value is 2.0E-3.

arguments.name: LSMAXITER=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of line-search iterations within one L-BFGS or conjugate gradient method.

arguments.name: LSWOLFE=
arguments.description: Specifies the Wolfe parameter c2 for the line-search technique. The default value is 0.7.

arguments.name: MAXITER=
arguments.description: Specifies that the optimization process stop after a maximum of N iterations.

arguments.name: MAXTIME=
arguments.description: Specifies an upper limit of M seconds of real time for the optimization process.

arguments.name: OBJLIMIT=
arguments.description: Specifies an upper limit on the magnitude of the objective value. For a minimization problem, the algorithm terminates when the objective value becomes less than -M; for a maximization problem, the algorithm stops when the objective value exceeds M.

arguments.name: OPTTOL=
arguments.description: Specifies the desired tolerance of the relative gradient norm.

arguments.name: PRINTFREQ=
arguments.description: Specifies that the printing of the solution progress to the iteration log should occur after every j iterations.

arguments.name: TECHNIQUE=
arguments.description: Specifies the optimization technique.

arguments.name: FLETREEV
arguments.description: Uses the Fletcher-Reeves nonlinear conjugate gradient algorithm.

arguments.name: LBFGS
arguments.description: Uses the limited-memory Broyden-Fletcher-Goldfarb-Shanno algorithm. This is the default solver.

arguments.name: POLRIB
arguments.description: Uses the Polak-Ribière nonlinear conjugate gradient algorithm.

arguments.name: CGTR
arguments.description: Uses the conjugate gradient method and a trust-region method to solve bound-constrained optimization problems.

statements.name: SOLVE WITH QP
statements.description: Statement for specifying and solving quadratic programs.
statements.help: SOLVE WITH QP NOOBJECTIVE OBJECTIVE RELAXINT ...

arguments.name: NOOBJECTIVE
arguments.description: Requests that the solver ignore the current objective for the problem and use a constant zero objective instead. This keyword enables the solver to process the current model as a feasibility problem.

arguments.name: OBJECTIVE
arguments.description: A keyword used when specifying the name of the objective to use.

arguments.name: RELAXINT
arguments.description: Requests that any integral variables be relaxed to be continuous. RELAXINT can be used with linear and nonlinear problems in addition to any solver.

arguments.name: IIS=
arguments.description: IIS=number | string Specifies whether the NLP solver attempts to identify a set of linear constraints and variables that form an irreducible infeasible set (IIS).

arguments.name: OFF
arguments.description: Disables IIS detection.

arguments.name: ON
arguments.description: Enables IIS detection.

arguments.name: LOGFREQ=
arguments.description: Specifies that the printing of the solution progress to the iteration log is to occur after every k iterations.

arguments.name: MAXITER=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of iterations.

arguments.name: MAXTIME=
arguments.description: Specifies an upper limit of k seconds of real time for the optimization process.

arguments.name: PRESOLVER=
arguments.description: Specifies one of the following presolve options:

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Disable presolver.

arguments.name: AUTOMATIC
arguments.description: Apply presolver by using default setting.

arguments.name: STOP_DG=
arguments.description: Specifies the desired relative duality gap, δ ϵ [1E–9, 1E–4]. This is the relative difference between the primal and dual objective function values and is the primary solution quality parameter. The default value is 1E–6.

arguments.name: STOP_DI=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum allowed relative dual constraints violation, β ϵ [1E–9, 1E–4]. The default value is 1E–6.

arguments.name: STOP_PI=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum allowed relative bound and primal constraints violation, α ϵ [1E–9, 1E–4]. The default value is 1E–6.

arguments.name: TIMETYPE=
arguments.description: Specifies the units of time used by the MAXTIME= option and reported by the PRESOLVE_TIME and SOLUTION_TIME terms in the _OROPTMODEL_ macro variable.

arguments.name: CPU
arguments.description: Specifies units of CPU time

arguments.name: REAL
arguments.description: Specifies units of real time

statements.name: SOLVE WITH SQP
statements.description: The sequential quadratic programming (SQP) solver is a component of the OPTMODEL procedure, and it can be used for solving general nonlinear programming (NLP) problems.
statements.help: SOLVE WITH SQP NOOBJECTIVE OBJECTIVE RELAXINT ...

arguments.name: NOOBJECTIVE
arguments.description: Requests that the solver ignore the current objective for the problem and use a constant zero objective instead. This keyword enables the solver to process the current model as a feasibility problem.

arguments.name: OBJECTIVE
arguments.description: A keyword used when specifying the name of the objective to use.

arguments.name: RELAXINT
arguments.description: Requests that any integral variables be relaxed to be continuous. RELAXINT can be used with linear and nonlinear problems in addition to any solver.

arguments.name: FEASTOL=
arguments.description: Specifies the convergence tolerance for feasibility. The value of this option is a positive real number. The default value is 1E-6.

arguments.name: HESCHECK
arguments.description: Specifies that the solver check the second-order optimality of the solution found - i.e., the nonnegativity of the projected Hessian of the Lagrangian function at the solution.

arguments.name: MAXITER=
arguments.description: Specifies that the optimization process stop after a maximum of N iterations.

arguments.name: MAXTIME=
arguments.description: Specifies an upper limit of r seconds of real time for the optimization process.

arguments.name: NOHESCHECK
arguments.description: Specifies that the solver does not check the second-order optimality of the solution found.

arguments.name: OPTTOL=
arguments.description: Specifies the convergence tolerance for both stationary and complementary conditions. The value of this option is a positive real number. The default value is 1E-5.

arguments.name: PENALTY=
arguments.description: Specifies the rate at which the penalty parameters used in the Lagrangian function are reduced. The default value for the PENALTY= option is 0.75.

arguments.name: PRINTFREQ=
arguments.description: Specifies that the printing of the solution progress to the iteration log should occur after every j iterations.

statements.name: STOP
statements.description: The STOP statement halts the execution of all statements that contain it, including DO statements and other control or looping statements. Execution continues with the next top-level source statement.

statements.name: STRING
statements.description: Declaration of parameters that have a STRING type.

arguments.name: INIT
arguments.description: Specifies a default value that is used when a parameter value is required but no other value has been supplied.

statements.name: SUBMIT
statements.description: The SUBMIT statement allows SAS code to be executed before PROC OPTMODEL processing continues. For example, you can use the SUBMIT statement to invoke other SAS procedures to perform analysis or to display results. The arguments list specifies macro variables to initialize in the SUBMIT block environment before the SUBMIT block is executed. List items are separated by spaces. Each of the arguments takes one of the following forms: name copies the value of the PROC OPTMODEL parameter name to the macro variable that has the same name. name = identifier-expression copies the value of the PROC OPTMODEL parameter specified by identifier-expression to the macro variable name. name = number | “string” | ‘string’ copies the value of the specified number or string constant to the macro variable name. name = ( expression ) copies the result of evaluating expression to the macro variable name.

arguments.name: OK=
arguments.description: specifies a PROC OPTMODEL numeric parameter location, identifier-expression, that is updated to indicate the success of the SUBMIT block execution. The location is set to 1 if execution is successful or 0 if errors are detected. PROC OPTMODEL continues execution when the SUBMIT block encounters errors only if the OK= option is specified.

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: specifies a single output-argument for retrieving macro variable values from the SUBMIT block environment after each execution of the block, or a list of space-delimited output-arguments for retrieving macro variable values from the SUBMIT block environment after the block is executed. Each output-argument item specifies a macro variable to copy out of the SUBMIT block environment after the block is executed. Each item takes one of the following two forms:

statements.name: UNFIX
statements.description: The UNFIX statement reverses the effect of FIX statements.

statements.name: USE PROBLEM
statements.description: The USE PROBLEM programming statement makes the problem specified by the identifier-expression be the current problem. If the problem has not been previously used, the problem is created using the PROBLEM declaration corresponding to the name. The problem must have been previously declared.

statements.name: VAR
statements.description: The VAR statement declares one or more optimization variables. Multiple VAR statements are permitted. A variable is not allowed to have the same name as a parameter or constraint.

arguments.name: BINARY
arguments.description: Requests that the solver assign the variable a value of either 0 or 1.

arguments.name: INIT
arguments.description: Sets an initial value for the variable. The expression is used only the first time the value is required. If no initial value is specified, then 0 is used by default.

arguments.name: INTEGER
arguments.description: Requests that the solver assign the variable an integer value.
